Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2009 07:59AM Laura3 wrote: No veritgo for me, just some mild nausea.  Most of my constant fatigue has gone away, I am at 21 out of 33.  I just seem to have it in weird unexpected waves, hitting when I least expect.  I guess thats better than constant....  I do have one question.  I am having 5-6 boosts at the end.  Can I expect anything new from that?  Any new skin stuff...fatigue, etc.  If any one has had the boosts and can let me know I would appreciate it.  I hope all of you are doing well and able to nap.....Take Care, Laura
Posts.Title: RADIATION FATIGUE - POLL bluejay1 Siciliana

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2009 04:40AM Laura3 wrote: Purpleme...Thanks for the info...I seem to have the same reaction you have, under the boob, on the side, and in front cleavage area.  They told me to use cortaid on the red bumps and that seems to help.  Not so itchy....After today I only have to go 9 more times....Can't wait to be over.  The only worry is that everyone seems to have the worst SE after its over.  So, I guess I can't feel so lucky yet.  Everything so far has been tolerable.  A little lotion and a good nap!  Hope you are all well, Laura
Posts.Title: RADIATION FATIGUE - POLL bluejay1 Siciliana

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2009 08:48AM Laura3 wrote: Elimar..... I just got back on here after a little break...Here is my story... I was diagnosed with DCIS, intermediate grade, atypical hyperplasia, focal necrosis.  I had two surgeries to get a clear margin, and 7 weeks of radiation. I just got the results from my genetic testing and I am negative.I have 3 aunts who had breast cancer all after the age of 60.  I was diagnosed at 50.    I finished rads on June 25.  I took a little break from my doctors and just saw my oncologist and surgeon.  Both are gently encouraging me to take the Tamoxifen.   They have been very informative and supportive of my decision.  This is the way they see it.....I have a 20% chance of developing a new breast cancer.  If I take the drug I cut those chances in half, so 10%. I have decided against it.  I am swimming, eating right and limiting alcohol.  I don't have any real extremes in my life, pretty much go with the moderation theory on everything.   Not perfect, but giving it a chance. The reason for my decision is this.   It is not the short term side effects that bother me, I can handle the hot flashes, mood swings, etc.  I have those anyway....got to love the menopausal symptoms!!!  It is the long term effects.  My sweet brother passed away last summer at the age of 56 of a sudden heart attack.  Perfect health, no weight issues, never drank, and was a doctor himself.  I now take a baby aspirin and a cholesterol medication and have a cardiologist.  My cholesterol has never been high, but they want it lower just as a precaution.  So, every 6 months I have to have blood work to make sure that medication is not effecting my liver.  AAAHHH........... So, the chance of developing a uterine cancer is just such a fun thought for me I can't stand it.  LIver, uterus, heart, breast...... Thats my story, I just don't want to take something and have to fix something else because of it. Not sure if all that makes sense.....I hope I helped a little... Take Care, God Bless, Laura
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy with radiation, but no hormonal threrapy elimar PauldingMom

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2009 01:00PM Laura3 wrote: Hello Ladies!   I had my first simulation last Wednesday.  I loved everyone at the office, but I also felt strange after the pictures were taken.   With all the news about naked pictures being texted around, I guess just want to make sure mine didn't make the rounds!  Oh, well at least the picture of my face and boobs were separate so no one can really know it is me.....  I also didn't realize how bad my arms would hurt by leaving them over my head for a long period of time.  OUCH... I am feeling a little anxious about getting started, I have the next simulation on May 4th and hopefully start treatment on the 11th.  Reading what you all have shared has helped me quite a bit.  The gastrointestinal issues  was a first for me, I hadn't heard that?  Does that happen everyday?    I also have another question....My doctor told me that many women wax their arm pit at the beginning.  Did any of you do that?  She told me she didn't want me to shave due the chance of infection.   I was going to do it, the idea of too much hair for 7 weeks doesn't sound comfortable, especially as we head into warm weather. I hope you are all doing well and feeling strong..... God Bless, Laura
